subordinate_units.composition: 2 field artillery groups (8 batteries), 1 AT company, 1 AA company

subordinate_units.unit_designation: 62° Sezione Sussistenza e Sezione Trasporti Motorizzati

tactical_doctrine.role: Static defense and limited offensive operations in North African desert terrain
special_capabilities: Autotrasportabile organization - could be transported by truck when vehicles available
Adapted for desert operations with animal transport backup
Extensive use of mule transport for rough terrain
known_issues: Insufficient motorization - only enough trucks to move portion of division at once
Obsolete artillery (WWI-era Austrian guns refurbished in 1933)
Binary (two-regiment) structure left division undermanned compared to three-regiment divisions
Personnel in support units lacked infantry training
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Mixed motor and animal transport system allowed operation when grounded from vehicles. Extensive mule train enabled mountain/rough terrain operations.

special_rules: Mixed transport: Can operate with reduced mobility when vehicles unavailable
Desert-adapted: No penalty for desert terrain
Weak AT defense: -1 modifier vs armor
Metropolitan division: Higher morale than colonial units
historical_engagements: Skirmishes at Fort Capuzzo (14 June - 23 July 1940)
Italian invasion of Egypt (9-16 September 1940) - covered Tenth Army right flank
Battle of Marmarica (11 December 1940) - positions at Sidi Omar untenable
Battle of Bardia (3-5 January 1941) - division destroyed

historical_notes.status_1940_q2: Fully operational, stationed at Bardia near Egyptian border. Preparing for potential operations following Italy's entry into WWII (10 June 1940).
historical_notes.combat_record: Division saw immediate action after Italy entered war. Skirmished with British forces at Fort Capuzzo from 14 June onwards. Participated in invasion of Egypt in September 1940, covering the Tenth Army's inland flank during advance to Sidi Barrani. Destroyed at Bardia on 5 January 1941 during British Operation Compass.
historical_notes.notable_features: Named after the ancient name for the surrounding region of Libya. Originally all three regiments (115th, 116th, 44th) were renamed 'Marmarica' in 1939 though they retained their original  'Treviso' designations in official records. Metropolitan division permanently stationed in Libya from formation.
historical_notes.fate: Destroyed during Battle of Bardia, 5 January 1941. Not reformed.

source: TM E 30-420 Handbook on Italian Military Forces (1943) - Infantry Division organization (sections 51-55)
Web search: Italian 62nd Marmarica Division historical records
Standard Italian Binary Division TO&E from TM E 30-420 Figure 6
known_gaps: Division commander name not documented in available sources (set to Unknown per user instructions)
Exact equipment variant distribution estimated from standard TO&E
Precise operational equipment counts estimated at 90-95% of authorized strength
WITW game IDs not available for Italian equipment
Precise dates for regiment renaming (1939) not confirmed
Exact composition of support units estimated from standard division TO&E
validation.data_quality_notes: Primary source data from US Army G-2 1943 order of battle document confirmed division composition (115th, 116th Infantry Regiments + 44th Artillery Regiment). Personnel and equipment numbers derived from standard Italian binary division TO&E documented in TM E 30-420. Historical context cross-referenced with multiple sources. Commander name not found despite extensive search - marked as Unknown per project guidelines (confidence <50% for this specific data point). Division destroyed in January 1941 so Q2 1940 represents early operational status.
validation.research_methodology: Three-tier source waterfall: (1) Primary local documents (US Army OOB, TM E 30-420), (2) Curated web sources for historical context, (3) Standard division TO&E applied where unit-specific data unavailable. Conservative estimates used for operational readiness (90-95% of authorized).
